Photo by Ron Baker (2011). | birth_name = James Darrell Scott | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|8|6}} | birth_place = [[London, Kentucky]], United States | origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], United States | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | instrument = Vocals, guitar, mandolin | years_active = 1990s–present | label = [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill]], Full Light | associated_acts = }} '''James Darrell Scott''', known as '''Darrell Scott''' (born August 6, 1959),{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/darrell-scott-mn0000566087 |title=Darrell Scott | Music Biography, Credits and Discography |website=[[AllMusic]] |date=August 6, 1959 |access-date=July 16, 2014}} is an American singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist. The son of musician Wayne Scott, he moved as a child to East Gary, Indiana (known today as [[Lake Station, Indiana|Lake Station]], Indiana). He was playing professionally by his teens in Southern California. Later, Darrell moved to Toronto then Boston. He attended [[Tufts University]], where he studied poetry and literature. He has lived in Nashville, Tennessee, since about 1995. He has written several mainstream [[country music|country]] hits, and he has also established himself as one of [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]]'s premier session instrumentalists. ==Musical career== [[File:BandOfJoy.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Scott (second-right) with [[Band of Joy]] at [[Birmingham Symphony Hall]], October 27, 2010]] Scott has collaborated with [[Steve Earle]], [[Sam Bush]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[John Cowan]], [[Verlon Thompson]], [[Guy Clark]], [[Tim O'Brien (musician)|Tim O'Brien]], [[Kate Rusby]], [[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]], [[Mary Gauthier]], [[Dan Tyminski]], and many others. His music has attracted a growing fanbase, and he tours regularly with his own band. His album, ''Crooked Road'', was released May 25, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/a-crooked-road-mw0001985519 |title=A Crooked Road – Darrell Scott | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |website=AllMusic |date=May 25, 2010 |access-date=July 16, 2014}} In early 2005, Scott's ''Theatre of the Unheard'' won in The 4th Annual Independent Music Awards for Album of the Year.[http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/jukeboxes2005.asp] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090702234906/http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/jukeboxes2005.asp|date=July 2, 2009}} He won the 2007 [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|''Song of the Year'' award]] from the [[Americana Music Association]] for his song "Hank William's Ghost"[http://americanamusic.org/index.htm?id=18347&sid=18331] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613002019/http://americanamusic.org/index.htm?id=18347&sid=18331|date=June 13, 2010}} which appears on his album ''The Invisible Man'' released in 2006. In 2010, he was announced as part of the [[Band of Joy]], alongside [[Robert Plant]], credited as performing vocals, mandolin, guitar, accordion, pedal, lap steel and banjo. In 2010, [[Brad Paisley]]'s cover of the song "You'll Never Leave Harlan Alive" was the closing song played on the TV drama [[Justified (TV series)|Justified]] during the final scene of the final episode of the first season. It was used again in the final episode of the second season.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/shows/justified/forums/youll-never-leave-harlan-alive-95927-3095548/ |title=Justified: "You'll Never Leave Harlan Alive" |website=TV.com |access-date=July 16, 2014}} The fourth season's final episode used a version by [[Dave Alvin]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aceweekly.com/2013/04/justified-season-4-finale-episode-13-ghosts/ |title=Justified Season 4 Finale, Episode 13 Ghosts |date=April 3, 2013 |publisher=Ace Weekly |access-date=July
